question_details.query: For large captive carnivores like felids and bears, what are the most effective food-based enrichment strategies to reduce stereotypic behaviours?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Presenting food frozen in ice decreased abnormal or stereotypic behaviours and increased activity levels in bears and felids [1923]. Providing food on a random temporal schedule has been found to reduce the frequency of stereotypic pacing in tigers and cheetahs [1904]. This unpredictable feeding schedule also increased behavioural diversity in red foxes and alertness in a black-footed cat [1904]. However, one study found that an unpredictable feeding schedule increased territorial behaviour in coyotes but did not affect travelling or foraging [1904]. For the strategy of presenting food frozen in ice, one study found that manipulation behaviours increased in lions, while another found that manipulation behaviours decreased in grizzly bears [1923]. There is no evidence for the effects of using food as a reward in animal training on captive carnivores [1928].
summary_statements: Presenting food frozen in ice decreased abnormal or stereotypic behaviours in bears and felids.
Presenting food frozen in ice increased activity levels in bears and felids.
Providing food on a random temporal schedule has been found to reduce the frequency of stereotypic pacing in tigers and cheetahs.
An unpredictable feeding schedule increased behavioural diversity in red foxes.
An unpredictable feeding schedule increased alertness in a black-footed cat.
One study found that an unpredictable feeding schedule increased territorial behaviour in coyotes.
An unpredictable feeding schedule did not affect travelling or foraging in coyotes.
For the strategy of presenting food frozen in ice, one study found that manipulation behaviours increased in lions.
For the strategy of presenting food frozen in ice, one study found that manipulation behaviours decreased in grizzly bears.
There is no evidence for the effects of using food as a reward in animal training on captive carnivores.

question_details.query: How do the effects of scattering food throughout a primate's enclosure compare with hiding it in containers?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Scattering food throughout an enclosure increased feeding and exploratory behaviours in rhesus macaques (1315), and increased foraging and activity levels in gorillas (1315). It also reduced abnormal behaviours in chimpanzees and aggression in lemurs (1315). Hiding food in containers, such as boxes, baskets or tubes, with the addition of browse, led to increased activity levels and foraging behaviours in lemurs and gibbons (1316).

question_details.query: What evidence exists for stimulating breeding in captive amphibians by manipulating environmental cues like temperature, rainfall, and sound?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two replicated, before-and-after studies in Germany and Austria found that simulating a wet and dry season stimulated breeding and egg deposition (1872). One before-and-after study in Austria found that captive frogs started breeding when housed in enclosures with more calling, perching and laying sites, as well as simulated wet and dry seasons (1876). One replicated study in Fiji found that adding rotting logs and hollow bamboo pipes to an enclosure promoted egg laying in frogs (1876). One replicated, before-and-after study in Australia found that the clutch size of frogs increased when females had mate choice, were exposed to recorded mating calls, and the sexes were separated during non-breeding periods (1888). No evidence was captured for the effects of allowing temperate amphibians to hibernate (1868).

question_details.query: For large felids in zoos, what are the observed behavioural and physiological outcomes of feeding whole carcasses versus providing bones or partial carcasses?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Feeding whole carcasses to lions, leopards, snow leopards, and cougars in zoos reduced pacing levels, though the same feeding regimen led to an increase in pacing for tigers (1901). In cheetahs, a diet of whole rabbit resulted in lower blood protein urea, zinc, and vitamin A levels compared to supplemented beef, and also showed lower levels of inflammatory bowel indicators (1901). When ocelots were fed whole chickens, they exhibited lower digestible energy and fat compared to a commercial diet (1901). For African wildcats, a whole chicken diet resulted in lower organic matter digestibility compared to a ground-chicken diet (1901). Providing bones to large felids, such as lions and tigers, was found to decrease the frequency of stereotypic behaviors and increase activity and manipulation time (1902).

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and harms of altering the frequency or timing of feeds for captive primates?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that when chimpanzees were fed on unpredictable schedules, their inactivity decreased [1338]. Another replicated, controlled study in the USA reported that an enrichment task took less time to complete when monkeys were in social groups than when feeding alone [1343]. A before-and-after study in Italy found that in the presence of their groupmates, monkeys ate more unfamiliar foods during the first encounter [1343]. No evidence was captured for the effects of providing primates access to food at all times (day and night) [1340].

question_details.query: For captive carnivores, how does hiding food around an enclosure compare to scattering it, in terms of behavioural changes?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Four replicated, before-and-after studies and one before-and-after study found that hiding food increased exploring and foraging behaviors in black bears, leopard cats, bush dogs, maned wolves and Malayan sun bears (1915). One replicated, before-and-after study and one before-and-after study in the USA found a decrease in stereotypical pacing in leopard cats and black bear after hiding food (1915). One study found that hiding food reduced the time Canadian lynx spent sleeping during the day (1915). One replicated, before-and-after study in Brazil found that scattered feeding increased locomotion in maned wolves (1921). Another replicated study in Brazil found that maned wolves spent more time in the section of their enclosure with scattered food than in a section with food on a tray (1921).

question_details.query: What evidence exists for the effectiveness of providing live prey to captive carnivores and primates to stimulate natural behaviours?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One before-and-after study in the UK found that when provided with live insect prey, inactivity reduced and foraging increased in captive loris to levels seen in wild loris (1333). For other mammals, three studies evaluated the effects of providing live natural prey to captive mammals to foster hunting behaviour before release. Two studies in Spain and Botswana found that a rehabilitated Iberian lynx and wild-born but captive-reared orphaned cheetahs and leopards that were provided with live natural prey in captivity survived for between at least three months and 19 months after release (2518). A controlled study in the USA found that captive-bred black-footed ferrets fed on live prairie dogs took longer to disperse after release but showed greater subsequent movements than did ferrets not fed with live prairie dogs (2518). One before-and-after study in the USA found that hunting behaviour increased and sleeping decreased when a fishing cat was provided with live fish. (1925). One replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that there was no change in the occurrence of stereotypical behaviours in tigers when provided with live fish (1925).

question_details.query: What dietary manipulations are available to improve breeding success and larval development in captive amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In one study, tadpoles fed a control diet of rabbit chow and fish food or freshwater algae had higher body mass and reached a more advanced developmental stage compared to those fed only pine or oak pollen; tadpoles fed only pollen did not undergo metamorphosis (1889). Another study found that tadpoles reared on a diet with 46% protein had higher growth rates, survival, and body weights at metamorphosis compared to those on diets with less protein (1889). For salamanders, egg production in captivity has been successful, with one study indicating that semi-natural tank habitats were more successful than laboratory conditions (838). Larval development, body condition, and survival of captive-bred amphibians were influenced by water temperature and density (838). There was no evidence found for the effects of supplementing diets with vitamins or calcium through dusting prey (1886) or gut-loading prey (1885).

question_details.query: In a zoo setting, what are the observed behavioural effects on bears of providing food frozen in ice versus inside other objects?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two replicated, before-and-after studies in the USA found that when presented with food frozen in ice, abnormal or stereotypic behaviours decreased and activity levels increased in bears and felids (1923). A replicated study in the USA found that manipulation behaviours decreased in grizzly bears when food was frozen in ice (1923).

question_details.query: How do the effects of providing carnivores with whole carcasses compare to the effects of providing live vertebrate prey?

summary_details.relevant_summary: A study in the USA found that feeding whole carcasses to lions, leopards, snow leopards and cougars reduced their pacing levels, but increased pacing in tigers (1901). In Denmark, cheetahs fed whole rabbits had lower blood protein urea, zinc and vitamin A levels compared to supplemented beef, and showed lower levels of inflammatory bowel indicators (1901). Another study in the USA found that when fed whole chickens, ocelots had lower digestible energy and fat compared to a commercial diet, and African wildcats had lower organic matter digestibility compared to a ground-chicken diet (1901). One study in the USA found that providing live fish to a fishing cat increased its hunting behaviour and decreased sleeping (1925). However, a replicated US study found no change in stereotypical behaviours in tigers when provided with live fish (1925).

question_details.query: To reduce anticipatory pacing in captive cheetahs, what are the alternatives to a standard, fixed feeding routine?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Altering the location of food around the enclosure has been found to decrease pacing behaviors in cheetahs (1918). Additionally, providing food on a random temporal schedule has been shown to reduce the frequency of stereotypic pacing behaviors in cheetahs (1904).

question_details.query: What is the state of the evidence regarding the provision of gum or nectar to captive primates?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No evidence was captured for the effects of providing gum (including artificial gum) to primates (1330). Additionally, no evidence was found for the effects of adding gum solutions to drilled hollow feeders for primates (1326), or for painting gum solutions on rough bark for primates (1325).

question_details.query: For captive primates, how do the behavioural effects of presenting food frozen in ice compare to presenting it in water?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two replicated and before-and-after studies in the USA and Ireland found that when food was presented in ice, feeding time increased and inactivity decreased for primates (1321). One replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that when exposed to water-filled troughs, monkeys were more active and increased their use of tools (1320).

question_details.query: What is the state of the evidence for providing captive primates with gum or nectar to encourage natural feeding behaviours?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No evidence was captured for the effects of providing gum (including artificial gum) to primates (1330). Additionally, no evidence was found for the effects of adding gum solutions to drilled hollow feeders (1326) or painting gum solutions on rough bark for primates (1325). 'No evidence' means that no studies that directly and quantitatively tested these actions were found during systematic journal and report searches, and therefore it is not known if the actions are effective or have any harmful impacts (1330, 1326, 1325).

question_details.query: For captive carnivores like maned wolves and cheetahs, what are the documented alternatives to a standard commercial diet for improving nutritional outcomes?

summary_details.relevant_summary: For maned wolves, a plant-derived protein diet increased digestible energy and dry matter digestibility but decreased mineral retention and plasma taurine levels when compared to an animal-based protein diet (1903). Supplementing an animal-protein diet with taurine increased plasma taurine levels in maned wolves (1908). When provided a commercial diet, maned wolves had similar dry matter intake and digestibility despite a lower protein content (1900). For cheetahs, a commercial diet resulted in a similar likelihood of developing gastritis as those fed horse meat, but with lower levels of blood protein urea and higher levels of creatine (1900). Also for cheetahs, a commercial meat diet or whole chicken carcasses resulted in plasma a-tocopherol, retinol and taurine concentrations within the ranges recommended for domestic cats (1900). For leopards, providing Jerusalem artichoke as a supplement increased two types of gut microbiota, faecal scores and faecal moisture content (1905). No evidence was found for the effect of supplementing meat-based diets with vitamins, minerals (1907) or fatty acids (1909) on captive carnivores.

question_details.query: What are the observed behavioural outcomes of providing live prey to captive primates and carnivores?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, providing live prey to captive primates and carnivores has yielded a range of behavioral outcomes. In one study, providing live insect prey to captive loris led to a reduction in inactivity and an increase in foraging to levels comparable to their wild counterparts (1333). For carnivores, the provision of live vertebrate prey was observed to increase hunting behavior and decrease sleeping time in a fishing cat (1925). However, in a separate study, providing live fish to tigers did not result in any change in the occurrence of stereotypical behaviors (1925). The introduction of live invertebrate prey for fennec foxes was found to increase their explorative behaviors when compared to other forms of enrichment (1926). In a study focused on preparing captive mammals for release, black-footed ferrets that were fed live prairie dogs demonstrated a longer time to dispersal but greater subsequent movements after being released (2518). Additionally, a rehabilitated Iberian lynx and orphaned cheetahs and leopards that had been provided with live natural prey in captivity were found to have survived for a minimum of three to nineteen months after their release (2518).

question_details.query: In a captive breeding program for Australian frogs, what are the most effective interventions to stimulate successful breeding?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In captive breeding programs for Australian frogs, hormone treatment has been shown to be an effective intervention. One review and nine of 10 replicated studies in several countries, including Australia, found that hormone treatment of male amphibians stimulated or increased sperm production or resulted in successful breeding in captivity (883). For female amphibians, hormone treatment has had mixed results, with some studies showing that it stimulated egg production or successful breeding, while others found it did not (883). In addition to hormone treatment, environmental manipulations have also been found to be effective. The reproductive success of frogs in captivity has been found to depend on temperature or a simulated wet and dry season (835). Furthermore, providing a variety of substrates, such as rotting logs and hollow bamboo pipes, has been shown to promote egg-laying in frogs (1874). One Australian study also found success by temporarily flooding enclosures, manipulating sex ratios, and playing recorded mating calls (1874).

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of modifying captive primate diets to better reflect what they would eat in the wild?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One study in the UK found that providing a fruit-free diet to lemurs led to a decrease in aggression and self-directed behaviour [1329]. In the USA, a study on gorillas found that substituting milk with fruit juice resulted in a reduction in regurgitation and reingestion [1329]. Another study in the USA involving rhesus macaques showed that offering fresh produce instead of pellet feed increased the time spent feeding and reduced inactivity [1335]. In two separate studies in Japan and the USA, increasing the number of daily feeds for chimpanzees led to more time spent feeding, but it also increased the incidence of hair eating in baboons [1337].

question_details.query: For captive carnivores, how does the effectiveness of hiding or scattering food compare to simply changing its location within the enclosure?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Hiding food around an enclosure was found in five studies to increase exploring and foraging behaviors in black bears, leopard cats, bush dogs, maned wolves, and Malayan sun bears (1915). Two of these studies also found a decrease in stereotypical pacing in leopard cats and black bears (1915). Another study found that hiding food reduced the time Canadian lynx spent sleeping during the day (1915). One study in Brazil found that scattering food increased locomotion in maned wolves and that they spent more time in the area with scattered food compared to food on a tray (1921). A study in Ireland on cheetahs found that altering the location of food decreased pacing behaviors (1918).

question_details.query: What is the state of evidence on presenting food that encourages or requires tool use in captive primates?

summary_details.relevant_summary: There is no evidence for the effects of presenting food to primates that requires the use or modification of tools (1319). However, two before-and-after studies in the USA and the UK found that using puzzle feeders increased tool use, foraging behavior, and aggression, but decreased food sharing (1318). A replicated, before-and-after study in the USA also found that puzzle feeders led to more time spent feeding and less inactivity (1318). Another replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that primates were more active and increased their tool use when food was presented in water-filled troughs (1320).

question_details.query: For captive felids, what are some effective alternatives to presenting food frozen in ice for reducing stereotypic behaviours?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The provision of bones, hides, or partial carcasses has been shown to be effective in reducing stereotypic behaviors in some captive felids. One study found that providing bones decreased the frequency of stereotypic behaviors in lions and tigers (1902). Additionally, providing bones was found to increase activity and manipulation time in felids (1902). Hiding food around the enclosure is another strategy that has been shown to be effective. One study found that hiding food decreased stereotypical pacing in leopard cats (1915). This method has also been found to increase exploring and foraging behaviors (1915).

question_details.query: What is the state of the evidence for providing primates with food that requires tool use or modification?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No evidence was found for the effects of presenting food to primates that requires the use or modification of tools (1319). This means that no studies that directly and quantitatively tested this action have been found (1319).

question_details.query: For improving the diet of captive primates, how does presenting whole foods instead of processed compare to providing fresh produce instead of pellets?

summary_details.relevant_summary: A before-and-after study in the USA on macaques showed that presenting whole foods instead of chopped foods led to an increase in the amount of food consumed and the time spent feeding (1323). In a separate replicated, before-and-after study in the USA, it was found that providing fresh produce instead of pellet feed to rhesus macaques resulted in more time spent feeding and less time being inactive (1335).

question_details.query: In a European zoo setting, what actions are available to simulate seasonal environmental changes to encourage breeding in captive amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two replicated, before-and-after studies in Germany and Austria found that simulating a wet and dry season using artificial rainfall, as well as moving amphibians to an enclosure with more egg laying sites and flowing water in Austria, stimulated breeding and egg deposition (1872). In the German study, no toadlets survived past 142 days old (1872). No evidence was found for the effects of varying enclosure humidity with humidifiers, foggers/misters, or artificial rain (1863), or for varying the duration of enclosure lighting to simulate seasonal changes in the wild (1866).

question_details.query: What are the observed behavioural and physiological outcomes of feeding captive primates a diet that more closely reflects their natural nutritional composition?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One before-and-after study in the USA found that when gorilla diets had milk replaced with fruit juice, there was a decrease in regurgitation and reingestion (1329). A replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that lemurs fed a fruit-free diet exhibited lower levels of aggression and self-directed behaviour (1329). In a replicated, before-and-after study in the USA, rhesus macaques that were given fresh produce instead of pellet feed spent more time feeding and less time inactive (1335). No evidence was found for the effects of providing nectar to primates (1331).

question_details.query: What are the trade-offs involved when feeding whole carcasses to captive carnivores?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two replicated, before-and-after studies in the USA found that feeding whole carcasses reduced pacing levels in lions, leopards, snow leopards and cougars, but increased pacing in tigers (1901). One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Denmark found that cheetahs fed whole rabbit had lower blood protein urea, zinc and vitamin A levels compared to supplemented beef (1901). One replicated before-and-after study in Denmark found that feeding whole rabbit showed lower levels of inflammatory bowel indicators in cheetahs (1901). One replicated, randomized study and one controlled study in the USA found that when fed whole 1 to 3 day old chickens, ocelots had lower digestible energy and fat compared to a commercial diet and African wildcats had had lower organic matter digestibility compared to a ground-chicken diet (1901). One before-and-after study in the USA found that hunting behaviour increased and sleeping decreased when a fishing cat was provided with live fish (1925).

question_details.query: To improve the welfare of captive maned wolves, what are the most effective dietary and food presentation interventions documented?

summary_details.relevant_summary: For captive maned wolves, a plant-derived protein diet was found to increase digestible energy and dry matter digestibility, but it also led to decreased mineral retention and plasma taurine levels when compared to an animal-based protein diet (1903). Providing a commercial diet resulted in similar dry matter intake and digestibility, despite a lower protein content (1900). Supplementing an animal-protein diet with taurine was found to increase plasma taurine levels (1908). In terms of food presentation, scattering food was found to increase locomotion in maned wolves, and they spent more time in the area of their enclosure with the scattered food (1921). Hiding food around the enclosure increased exploring and foraging behaviors in maned wolves and other carnivores (1915).
